body.p: As we explained in the introduction, multiple regression extends simple regression in that we have more than one explanatory variable. We will use the letter k as a notation for the number of explanatory variables we’re considering. Our goal is to examine the relationship between the explanatory variables X1, X2, X3,….Xk and the response Y, and the following figure gives and outline of the process:

image.alt: Using a statistical model that relates Y to x1, x2, ....., xk, and based on the observed data, we draw conclusions about the relationship between these variables in the population

ol.li: Note that since we have k explanatory variables, the dataset that we’re working with is much more complex than in simple regression where for each of then subjects we had two observations; one X observation and one Y observation. Here, for each of the n subjects we have k+1 observations; one for each of the k explanatory variables, and one for the response.

As you remember from simple regression, and as the pink box emphasizes, the inference part of the analysis will be centered around a statistical model for the relationship between the explanatory variables and will be based on the observed data from out sample.

body.p: Here is how we’ll proceed from here

ul.li: First, we’ll be introduced to the example that will carry us through this section.
We’ll then discuss the EDA (Exploratory Data Analysis) part of the analysis.
We’ll do some simple regressions which we’ll need later for comparison with the multiple regression analysis
Finally, we’ll introduce the multiple regression statistical model and conduct the analysis.
